item.title: The Google Spain ruling by the CJEU: a lack of equilibrium between privacy and freedom of speech
item.description:
By Steve Peers The EU’s data protection Directive was established in 1995 during the early days of the internet, before the rise of major internet companies. Notably, Google, founded in 1998, emerged just as EU countries were implementing this Directive. Despite its age and ongoing debates surrounding a proposed revision, this legislation still governs the modern internet. item.title: Is the UK's new data retention bill in violation of the EU Charter of Fundamental Rights?
item.description:
Steve Peers Despite the Court of Justice of the European Union (CJEU) invalidating the EU’s data retention directive in April, the UK government is pushing for continued data retention authority. This piece examines whether the proposed law aligns with EU law and if it violates the EU Charter of Fundamental Rights. The connection to EU law lies in Article 15(1) of the EU’s e-privacy Directive. This article allows Member States to restrict certain rights concerning communication confidentiality for safeguarding national security and other serious matters...

item.title: The Tele 2 and Watson case: Human Rights and National Data Retention Law
item.description:
Lorna Woods, Professor of Internet Law, University of Essex The Advocate General recently issued an opinion on two cases referred by national courts. Both cases examine whether the mass retention of communications data aligns with EU law, raising a critical question: can such broad data retention ever truly comply with human rights?..
